qas.question: What act determined what class a citizen belonged to?
What test was used to determine if someone was coloured or black?
How did the pencil test work?

answers.text: A pencil was inserted into a person's hair to determine if the hair was kinky enough to hold the pencil

context: The apartheid bureaucracy devised complex (and often arbitrary) criteria in <a0_0>the Population Registration Act of 1945<a0_0/> to determine who belonged in which group. <a3_0>Minor officials<a3_0/> administered tests to enforce the classifications. When it was unclear from a person's physical appearance whether the individual should be considered Coloured or Black, the "<a1_0>pencil test<a1_0/>" was used. <a2_0>A pencil was inserted into a person's hair to determine if the hair was kinky enough to hold the pencil<a2_0/>, rather than having it pass through, as it would with smoother hair. If so, the person was classified as Black. Such classifications sometimes divided families.
